content: How do I tell pip to use an alternative index, specifically http://dist.repoze.org/zope2/2.10/simple/, when installing packages from a requirements file for a repoze Zope2 install? I have tried various permutations in my requirements.txt file and using the '-i' option with the pip install command, but none of these attempts have been successful.

To instruct `pip` to use an alternative index URL when installing packages from a requirements file, you can specify the index URL directly within your `requirements.txt` file or use the `-i` option with the `pip install` command. Here are two methods you can try:

### Method 1: Within `requirements.txt`

You can specify the index URL at the top of your `requirements.txt` file by using the `--index-url` option. Here is how you can do it:

```
--index-url http://dist.repoze.org/zope2/2.10/simple/
# List your packages below
package_name1==version
package_name2==version
```

### Method 2: Using the `-i` option with `pip install`

Alternatively, you can specify the index URL directly when running the `pip install` command. Here's how you can do that:

```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt -i http://dist.repoze.org/zope2/2.10/simple/
```

### Additional Option: Use `--extra-index-url`

If you want to use this index in addition to the default PyPI index, you can use the `--extra-index-url` option:

```bash
--extra-index-url http://dist.repoze.org/zope2/2.10/simple/
```

### Note

Make sure that the specified URL in your configuration is correct and accessible. Also, verify that any required authentication or network settings are properly configured, especially if you're working behind a proxy or firewall.

By using these methods, `pip` should be able to access the specified alternative index URL and install the necessary packages from there.
